description:
[Chinese tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_tea), hot, loose leaf tea served in a big pot, originated thousands of years ago (legend has it that it was discovered when tea leaves accidentally landed in hot water) and is so integral to dim sum (teahouses actually predate the advent of dim sum) that 飲茶 *yám chàh* (Cantonese for *drink tea*) also means to go out for dim sum. 

**Varieties**

There is a huge variety of Chinese tea, which can be split into categories such as green, black, white, scented... Jasmine and oolong tea is standard, and chrysanthemum is a common non-caffeinated option, but large Chinese restaurants usually offer many more (I once asked “what tea do you have?” and they responded “what do you want?”

**Books**

[A Little Tea Book](https://inpursuitoftea.com/products/little-tea-book) by Simon Beckwith describes the varieties of teas (not just Chinese), their characteristics, and proper preparation. [The Dim Sum Field Guide](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/533493/the-dim-sum-field-guide-by-carolyn-phillips/) by Carolyn Phillips lists teas commonly served with dim sum.

description: For over the past hundred years, there have been various official and unofficial lists of [top ten Chinese teas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Chinese_teas#Ten_Famous_Teas), so if you combine all the different lists, it's a lot more than ten! Teas that have made the lists(s) include West Lake Dragon Well, Dongting Biluochun, Huangshan Maofeng, Lu Shan Cloud, Xinyang Maojian, Wuyi tea, Tieguanyin, and Keemun.

description:
**Origin Story**

The first commercial tea bags (although not the first patented tea bags) were developed over a hundred years ago by Thomas Sullivan, a New York coffee and tea importer. Legend has it that his silk tea bags were only meant for packaging but customers just brewed the whole thing, and eureka, a product was born!
